<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	2016 Compared with 2015
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Net loss from continuing operations decreased $262&nbsp;million in 2016 as compared to 2015. In 2015, CNA recognized a
	$177&nbsp;million
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	(after-tax
</FONT>
	and noncontrolling interests) charge relating to a premium deficiency and claim reserve strengthening in its long term care business. The December&nbsp;31, 2015 Gross Premium
	Valuation (&#147;GPV&#148;) indicated a premium deficiency of $296&nbsp;million. The indicated premium deficiency necessitated a charge to income that was effected by the write off of the entire long term care deferred acquisition cost of
	$289&nbsp;million and an increase to active life reserves of $7&nbsp;million. Due to the recognition of the premium deficiency and resetting of actuarial assumptions in the fourth quarter of 2015, the operating results of CNA&#146;s long term care
	business in 2016 reflect the variance between actual experience and the expected results contemplated in its best estimate reserves.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In 2016, the long term care business recorded net operating income of $18&nbsp;million (after tax and noncontrolling
	interests), driven by a favorable release of claim reserves resulting from the annual claims experience study and higher net investment income due to an increase in the invested asset base. The long term care results were generally in line with
	expectations, as the impact of favorable morbidity was partially offset by unfavorable persistency. In 2015, results of CNA&#146;s long term care business reflected variances between actual experience and actuarial assumptions that were
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	locked-in
</FONT>
	at policy issuance. As a result of the reserve assumption unlocking, the 2016 and 2015 results are not comparable. For further discussion of the GPV and premium deficiency, see the Insurance Reserves
	section of this MD&amp;A.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Results in 2016 and 2015 were also negatively affected by $74&nbsp;million and $49&nbsp;million
	(after tax and noncontrolling interests) charges related to the application of retroactive reinsurance accounting to adverse reserve development ceded under the 2010 A&amp;EP loss portfolio transfer, as further discussed in Note 8 of the Notes to
	Consolidated Financial Statements included under Item 8.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	2015 Compared with 2014
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Net loss from continuing operations increased $264&nbsp;million in 2015 as compared with 2014 driven by the $177&nbsp;million
	(after tax and noncontrolling interests) charge related to recognition of a premium deficiency and claim reserve strengthening in CNA&#146;s long term care business, discussed above. Excluding the effects of this item, results in 2015 were also
	negatively affected by higher morbidity in CNA&#146;s long term care business. Results in 2014 were negatively affected by a $31&nbsp;million loss (after tax and noncontrolling interests) on a coinsurance transaction related to the sale of
	CNA&#146;s former life insurance subsidiary.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Results in 2015 were also negatively impacted by an increase in gross
	A&amp;EP claim reserves. While all of this reserve development is reinsured under the loss portfolio transfer, only a portion of the reinsurance recovery is currently recognized because of the application of retroactive reinsurance accounting. As a
	result, a charge of $84&nbsp;million ($49&nbsp;million after tax and noncontrolling interests) was recorded in 2015, as further discussed in Note 8 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included under Item&nbsp;8. Additionally, results
	in 2015 benefited from lower interest expense due to the maturity of higher coupon debt in the fourth quarter of 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	56
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage57"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D284597D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Referendum on the United Kingdom&#146;s Membership in the European Union
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	On June&nbsp;23, 2016, the United Kingdom (&#147;U.K.&#148;) held a referendum in which voters approved an exit from the
	European Union (&#147;E.U.&#148;), commonly referred to as &#147;Brexit.&#148; As a result of the referendum, it is currently expected that the British government will formally commence the process to leave the E.U. and begin negotiating the terms
	of treaties that will govern the U.K.&#146;s future relationship with the E.U. in the first quarter of 2017. Although the terms of any future treaties are unknown, changes in CNA&#146;s international operating platform may be required to allow CNA
	to continue to write business in the E.U. after the completion of Brexit. As a result of these changes, the complexity and cost of regulatory compliance of CNA&#146;s European business is likely to increase.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<A NAME="D284597D10K_HTM_TX284597_105">
</A>
	Diamond Offshore
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Overview
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Oil prices, which had fallen to a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	12-year
</FONT>
	low of less than $30 per barrel in
	January of 2016, rebounded to some extent into the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	low-to-mid-$50s
</FONT>
</FONT>
</FONT>
	per barrel range by the end of January of 2017, in part due to
	expectations that an agreement to cut production by certain members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (&#147;OPEC&#148;) and others that went into effect in 2017 would reduce the oversupply of oil and raise and potentially
	stabilize oil prices. To date, however, oil prices have continued to exhibit volatility due to multiple factors, including fluctuations in the current and expected level of global oil inventories and estimates of global demand. Despite the recent
	rise in oil prices and announcements by a few customers of planned increases in capital spending in 2017, Diamond Offshore expects that overall capital spending for offshore exploration and development in 2017 will be lower than 2016 levels. As a
	consequence, the offshore contract drilling industry remains weak.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Industry analysts have reported that in 2016, for the
	second consecutive year, the global supply of floater rigs decreased with 24 floaters being scrapped during the year. In addition, many drilling rigs across all water depth categories were cold stacked in 2016. Despite these events, the oversupply
	of drilling rigs in the floater markets continues to persist. Industry reports indicate that only three newbuild floaters were delivered in 2016; however, there are approximately 40 newbuild floaters scheduled for delivery between 2017 and 2021.
	Industry analysts predict that these delivery dates may extend further as newbuild owners negotiate with their respective shipyards.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Given the oversupply of rigs, competition for the limited number of offshore drilling jobs continues to be intense. In some
	cases, dayrates have been negotiated at break-even or below-cost levels in order to enable the drilling contractor to recover a portion of operating costs for rigs that would otherwise be uncontracted or cold stacked. In addition, customers have
	indicated a preference for &#147;hot&#148; rigs rather than reactivated cold-stacked rigs. This preference incentivizes the drilling contractor to contract rigs at lower rates for the sole purpose of maintaining the rigs in an active state and
	allowing for at least partial cost recovery. Industry analysts have predicted that the offshore contract drilling market will remain depressed through 2017.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	As a result of the continuing depressed market conditions in the offshore drilling industry and continued pessimistic outlook
	for the near term, certain of Diamond Offshore&#146;s customers, as well as those of its competitors, have attempted to renegotiate or terminate existing drilling contracts. Such renegotiations have included requests to lower the contract dayrate in
	some cases in exchange for additional contract term, shorten the term on one contracted rig in exchange for additional term on another rig, to early terminate a contract in exchange for a lump sum payout and other requests. In addition to the
	potential for renegotiations, some of Diamond Offshore&#146;s drilling contracts permit the customer to terminate the contract early after specified notice periods, usually resulting in a requirement for the customer to pay a contractually specified
	termination amount, which may not fully compensate Diamond Offshore for the loss of the contract. As a result of these depressed market conditions, some customers have also utilized such contract clauses to seek to renegotiate or terminate a
	drilling contract or claim that Diamond Offshore has breached provisions of its drilling contracts in order to avoid their obligations to Diamond Offshore under circumstances where Diamond Offshore believes it is in compliance with the contracts.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	57
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage58"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D284597D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Particularly during depressed market conditions, the early termination of a
	contract may result in a rig being idle for an extended period of time, which could adversely affect Diamond Offshore&#146;s business. When a customer terminates a contract prior to the contract&#146;s scheduled expiration, Diamond Offshore&#146;s
	contract backlog is also adversely impacted.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Diamond Offshore&#146;s results of operations and cash flows for the years
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015 have been materially impacted by depressed market conditions in the offshore drilling industry. Diamond Offshore currently expects that these adverse market conditions will continue for the foreseeable future.
	The continuation of these conditions for an extended period could result in more of Diamond Offshore&#146;s rigs being without contracts and/or cold stacked or scrapped and could further materially and adversely affect its financial condition,
	results of operations and cash flows. When Diamond Offshore cold stacks or elects to scrap a rig, it evaluates the rig for impairment. During 2016, Diamond Offshore recognized an aggregate impairment loss of $680&nbsp;million, related to eight of
	its drilling rigs and related spare parts and supplies. During 2015, Diamond Offshore recognized an aggregate impairment loss of $861&nbsp;million related to 17 of its drilling rigs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Historically, the longer a drilling rig remains cold stacked, the higher the cost of reactivation and, depending on the age,
	technological obsolescence and condition of the rig, the lower the likelihood that the rig will be reactivated at a future date. As of January&nbsp;30, 2017, ten rigs in Diamond Offshore&#146;s fleet were cold stacked.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Contract Drilling Backlog
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Diamond Offshore&#146;s contract drilling backlog was $3.6&nbsp;billion, $4.1&nbsp;billion and $5.2&nbsp;billion as of
	January&nbsp;1, 2017 (based on contract information known at that time), October&nbsp;1, 2016 (the date reported in our Quarterly Report on Form
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	10-Q
</FONT>
	for the quarter ended September&nbsp;30, 2016) and
	February&nbsp;16, 2016 (the date reported in our Annual Report on Form
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	10-K
</FONT>
	for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015). The contract drilling backlog by year as of January&nbsp;1, 2017 is $1.5&nbsp;billion in
	2017, $1.1&nbsp;billion in 2018, $0.8&nbsp;billion in 2019 and $0.2&nbsp;billion in 2020. Contract drilling backlog includes $158&nbsp;million, $158&nbsp;million, $150&nbsp;million and $6&nbsp;million for 2017, 2018, 2019 and 2020 attributable to
	the
<I>
	Ocean GreatWhite
</I>
	, which reflects a revised standby rate that allows Diamond Offshore to pass along certain cost savings to its customer while maintaining approximately the same operating margin and cash flows as the original contract and
	$149&nbsp;million and $119&nbsp;million for 2017 and 2018 attributable to contracted work for the
<I>
	Ocean Valor
</I>
	under a contract that Petr&oacute;leo Brasileiro S.A. (&#147;Petrobras&#148;) has attempted to terminate and is currently in effect
	pursuant to an injunction granted by a Brazilian court, which Petrobras has appealed.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Contract drilling backlog includes
	only firm commitments (typically represented by signed contracts) and is calculated by multiplying the contracted operating dayrate by the firm contract period. Diamond Offshore&#146;s calculation also assumes full utilization of its drilling
	equipment for the contract period (excluding scheduled shipyard and survey days); however, the amount of actual revenue earned and the actual periods during which revenues are earned will be different than the amounts and periods stated above due to
	various factors affecting utilization such as weather conditions and unscheduled repairs and maintenance. Contract drilling backlog excludes revenues for mobilization, demobilization, contract preparation and customer reimbursables. Changes in
	Diamond Offshore&#146;s contract drilling backlog between periods are generally a function of the performance of work on term contracts, as well as the extension or modification of existing term contracts and the execution of additional contracts.
	In addition, under certain circumstances, Diamond Offshore&#146;s customers may seek to terminate or renegotiate its contracts, which could adversely affect its reported backlog.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Results of Operations
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Diamond Offshore&#146;s pretax income (loss) is primarily a function of contract drilling revenue earned less contract
	drilling expenses incurred or recognized. The two most significant variables affecting Diamond Offshore&#146;s contract drilling revenues are dayrates earned and rig utilization rates achieved by its rigs, each of which is a function of rig supply
	and demand in the marketplace. Revenues can also be affected as a result of the acquisition or disposal of rigs, rig mobilizations, required surveys and shipyard projects.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	58
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage59"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D284597D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Operating expenses represent all direct and indirect costs associated with the
	operation and maintenance of Diamond Offshore&#146;s drilling equipment. The principal components of Diamond Offshore&#146;s operating costs are, among other things, direct and indirect costs of labor and benefits, repairs and maintenance, freight,
	regulatory inspections, boat and helicopter rentals and insurance.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The following table summarizes the results of
	operations for Diamond Offshore for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014 as presented in Note 20 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included under Item 8:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	2016 Compared with 2015
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Contract drilling revenue decreased $835&nbsp;million in 2016 as compared with 2015 due to continued depressed market
	conditions in all floater markets and for the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	jack-up
</FONT>
	rig. The decrease in contract drilling revenues for ultra-deepwater and deepwater floater fleets was primarily due to currently cold stacked rigs that had
	operated in 2015, lower amortized mobilization and contract preparation fees and lower dayrates earned by the
<I>
	Ocean Valiant
</I>
	and
<I>
	Ocean Apex
</I>
	. The decrease in contract drilling revenues for the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	mid-water
</FONT>
	and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	jack-up
</FONT>
	fleets was primarily due to fewer
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	mid-water
</FONT>
	floaters operating under contract in 2016 compared to 2015 and
	the early contract termination for the
<I>
	Ocean Scepter
</I>
	in 2016, which is expected to commence operations offshore Mexico in the first quarter of 2017. These decreases were partially offset by the favorable settlement of a contractual dispute of
	$36&nbsp;million and receipt of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	loss-of-hire
</FONT>
</FONT>
	insurance proceeds in 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Contract drilling expense decreased $456&nbsp;million in 2016 as compared with 2015, reflecting Diamond Offshore&#146;s lower
	cost structure due to additional rigs idled, cold stacked or retired during 2015 and 2016, as well as the favorable impact of cost control initiatives. Asset impairment charges decreased $201&nbsp;million as compared with the prior year. As a result
	of the impairment charges in 2015 and 2016 and resulting lower depreciable asset base, depreciation expense decreased $111&nbsp;million in 2016 as compared to 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Net results decreased $30&nbsp;million in 2016 as compared with 2015, primarily due to lower utilization of the rig fleet,
	which reduced both contract drilling revenue and expense for the year. Results for 2016 also reflected an aggregate impairment charge of $267&nbsp;million (after taxes and noncontrolling interests) compared to impairment charges aggregating
	$341&nbsp;million (after taxes and noncontrolling interests) in 2015. In addition, during 2016, Diamond Offshore sold its investment in privately-held corporate bonds for a total recognized loss of $12&nbsp;million ($4&nbsp;million after tax and
	noncontrolling interests). The lower results were partially offset by a decrease in depreciation expense, recognition of $40&nbsp;million in demobilization revenue and $15&nbsp;million in net reimbursable revenue related to the
<I>
	Ocean
	Endeavor
</I>
	&#146;s demobilization from the Black Sea and the absence of a $20&nbsp;million
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	59
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage60"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D284597D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	impairment charge in 2015 to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	write-off
</FONT>
	all goodwill associated with the Company&#146;s investment in Diamond Offshore. In addition, results in 2016 were
	favorably impacted by a $43&nbsp;million tax adjustment primarily related to Diamond Offshore&#146;s Egyptian liability for uncertain tax positions related to the devaluation of the Egyptian pound.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	2015 Compared with 2014
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Contract drilling revenue decreased $377&nbsp;million in 2015 as compared with 2014, primarily due to a decrease in revenue
	earned by both the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	mid-water
</FONT>
	and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	jack-up
</FONT>
	fleets, partially offset by an increase in revenue earned by both the ultra-deepwater and deepwater floaters. The decrease in
	contract drilling revenue was primarily due to cold stacking, rig sales and incremental downtime between contracts for several rigs. During 2015, twelve
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	mid-water
</FONT>
	rigs were cold stacked or retired and five
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	jack-up
</FONT>
	rigs were cold stacked and marketed for sale. These decreases were partially offset by increased incremental revenue earning days for newly constructed ultra-deepwater floaters and upgraded or enhanced rigs.
	In addition, during 2015, four deepwater floaters returned to operation after prolonged periods of nonproductive time for planned upgrades and surveys, as well as warm-stacking between contracts.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Contract drilling expense decreased $296&nbsp;million in 2015 as compared with 2014, primarily due to lower rig utilization,
	combined with efforts to control costs. This decrease in expenses was partially offset by an increase in depreciation expense due to a higher depreciable asset base in 2015, including the
<I>
	Ocean Apex
</I>
	and two drillships, which were placed in
	service in December of 2014, partially offset by the absence of depreciation for certain rigs that were impaired or sold during late 2014 and in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	A net loss of $156&nbsp;million in 2015 and net income of $183&nbsp;million in 2014 resulted in a change of $339&nbsp;million
	due to the impact of a $341&nbsp;million asset impairment charge (after tax and noncontrolling interests) in 2015 related to the carrying value of 17 drilling rigs, as compared to the prior year when Diamond Offshore recorded a $55&nbsp;million
	asset impairment charge (after tax and noncontrolling interests) related to the carrying values of six drilling rigs. Results in 2015 also include the recognition of a $20&nbsp;million impairment charge to write off all goodwill associated with the
	Company&#146;s investment in Diamond Offshore as well as higher depreciation and interest expense.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<A NAME="D284597D10K_HTM_TX284597_106">
</A>
	Boardwalk Pipeline
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Overview
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Boardwalk Pipeline derives revenues primarily from the transportation and storage of natural gas and natural gas liquids
	(&#147;NGLs&#148;). Transportation services consist of firm natural gas transportation, where the customer pays a capacity reservation charge to reserve pipeline capacity at receipt and delivery points along pipeline systems, plus a commodity and
	fuel charge on the volume of natural gas actually transported, and interruptible natural gas transportation, under which the customer pays to transport gas only when capacity is available and used. The transportation rates Boardwalk Pipeline is able
	to charge customers are heavily influenced by market trends (both short and longer term), including the available natural gas supplies, geographical location of natural gas production, the demand for gas by
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	end-users
</FONT>
	such as power plants, petrochemical facilities and liquefied natural gas (&#147;LNG&#148;) export facilities and the price differentials between the gas supplies and the market demand for the gas
	(basis differentials). Rates for short term firm and interruptible transportation services are influenced by shorter term market conditions such as current and forecasted weather.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Boardwalk Pipeline offers firm natural gas storage services in which the customer reserves and pays for a specific amount of
	storage capacity, including injection and withdrawal rights, and interruptible storage and parking and lending (&#147;PAL&#148;) services where the customer receives and pays for capacity only when it is available and used. The value of Boardwalk
	Pipeline&#146;s storage and PAL services (comprised of parking gas for customers and/or lending gas to customers) is affected by natural gas price differentials between time periods, such as between winter and summer (time period price spreads),
	price volatility of natural gas and other factors. Boardwalk Pipeline&#146;s storage and parking services have greater value when the natural gas futures market is in contango (a positive time period price spread, meaning that current price quotes
	for delivery of natural gas further in the future are higher than in the nearer term), while its lending service has greater value when the futures market is backwardated (a negative time period price spread, meaning that current price quotes for
	delivery of natural gas in the nearer term are higher than further in the future). The value of both storage and PAL services may also be favorably impacted by increased volatility in the price of natural gas, which allows Boardwalk Pipeline to
	optimize the value of its storage and PAL capacity.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	60
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage61"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D284597D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Boardwalk Pipeline also transports and stores NGLs. Contracts for Boardwalk
	Pipeline&#146;s NGLs services are generally fee based or based on minimum volume requirements, while others are dependent on actual volumes transported. Boardwalk Pipeline&#146;s NGLs storage rates are market-based and contracts are typically fixed
	price arrangements with escalation clauses. Boardwalk Pipeline is not in the business of buying and selling natural gas and NGLs other than for system management purposes, but changes in natural gas and NGLs prices may impact the volumes of natural
	gas or NGLs transported and stored by customers on its systems. Due to the capital intensive nature of its business, Boardwalk Pipeline&#146;s operating costs and expenses typically do not vary significantly based upon the amount of products
	transported, with the exception of fuel consumed at its compressor stations and not included in a fuel tracker.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Firm Transportation Agreements
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	A substantial portion of Boardwalk Pipeline&#146;s transportation capacity is contracted for under firm
	transportation agreements. Actual revenues recognized from capacity reservation and minimum bill charges in 2016 were $1.0&nbsp;billion. Approximate projected revenues from capacity reservation and minimum bill charges under committed firm
	transportation agreements in place as of December&nbsp;31, 2016 are $1.1&nbsp;billion for 2017 and $975&nbsp;million for 2018. The amounts for 2016 and 2017 increased approximately $13&nbsp;million and $25&nbsp;million from what was reported in our
	2015 Form
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	10-K.
</FONT>
	The increase in each year is primarily due to contract renewals and new contracts that were entered into during 2016. Additional revenues Boardwalk Pipeline has recognized and may receive under
	firm transportation agreements based on actual utilization of the contracted pipeline capacity, any expected revenues for periods after the expiration dates of the existing agreements, execution of precedent agreements associated with growth
	projects or other events that occurred or will occur subsequent to December&nbsp;31, 2016 are not included in these amounts.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Each year a portion of Boardwalk Pipeline&#146;s firm transportation agreements expire and need to be renewed or replaced. In
	the 2018 to 2020 timeframe, the agreements associated with the East Texas Pipeline, Southeast Expansion, Gulf Crossing Pipeline and Fayetteville and Greenville Laterals, which were placed into service in 2008 and 2009, will expire. These projects
	were large, new pipeline expansions, developed to serve growing production in Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and Louisiana and anchored primarily by
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	10-year
</FONT>
	firm transportation agreements with producers. Since
	Boardwalk Pipeline&#146;s expansion projects went into service, gas production from the Utica and Marcellus area in the Northeast has grown significantly and has altered the flow patterns of natural gas in North America. Over the last few years, gas
	production from other basins such as Barnett and Fayetteville, which primarily supported two of Boardwalk Pipeline&#146;s expansions, has declined because the production economics in those basins are not as competitive as other production basins,
	such as Utica and Marcellus. These market dynamics have resulted in less production from certain basins tied to Boardwalk Pipeline&#146;s system and a narrowing of basis differentials across portions of its pipeline systems, primarily for capacity
	associated with natural gas flows from west to east. Boardwalk Pipeline expects that the total revenues generated from the expansion projects&#146; capacity could be materially lower when these contracts expire.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Boardwalk Pipeline&#146;s marketing efforts are focused on enhancing the value of this expansion capacity. Boardwalk Pipeline
	is working with customers to match gas supplies from various basins to new and existing customers and markets, including aggregating supplies at key locations along its pipelines to provide
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	end-use
</FONT>
	customers
	with attractive and diverse supply options.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Partially as a result of the increase in overall gas supplies, demand
	markets, primarily in the Gulf Coast area, are growing due to new natural gas export facilities, power plants and petrochemical facilities and increased exports to Mexico. These developments have resulted in significant growth projects for Boardwalk
	Pipeline. Boardwalk Pipeline placed into service approximately $320&nbsp;million of growth projects in 2016, and have an additional $1.3&nbsp;billion of growth projects under development that are expected to be placed into service in 2017 and 2018.
	These new projects have lengthy planning and construction periods and, as a result, will not contribute to Boardwalk Pipeline&#146;s earnings and cash flows until they are placed into service over the next several years. The revenues generated that
	are expected to be realized in 2017 and 2018 from these projects are included in the amounts above.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	61
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage62"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D284597D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Pipeline System Maintenance
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Boardwalk Pipeline incurs substantial costs for ongoing maintenance of its pipeline systems and related facilities, including
	those incurred for pipeline integrity management activities, equipment overhauls, general upkeep and repairs. These costs are not dependent on the amount of revenues earned from its natural gas transportation services. The Pipeline and Hazardous
	Materials Safety Administration (&#147;PHMSA&#148;) has developed regulations that require transportation pipeline operators to implement integrity management programs to comprehensively evaluate certain areas along pipelines and take additional
	measures to protect pipeline segments located in highly populated areas. These regulations have resulted in an overall increase in ongoing maintenance costs, including maintenance capital and maintenance expense. PHMSA has proposed more prescriptive
	regulations, including expanded integrity management requirements, automatic or remote-controlled valve use, leak detection system installation, pipeline material strength testing and verification of maximum allowable pressures of certain pipelines,
	which if implemented, could require Boardwalk Pipeline to incur significant additional costs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Maintenance costs may be
	capitalized or expensed, depending on the nature of the activities. For any given reporting period, the mix of projects that Boardwalk Pipeline undertakes will affect the amounts it records as property, plant and equipment on its balance sheet or
	recognize as expenses, which impacts Boardwalk Pipeline&#146;s earnings. In 2017, Boardwalk Pipeline expects to spend approximately $340&nbsp;million to maintain its pipeline systems, of which approximately $140&nbsp;million is expected to be
	maintenance capital. In 2016, Boardwalk Pipeline spent $321&nbsp;million, of which $121&nbsp;million was recorded as maintenance capital. The maintenance capital amounts include pipeline integrity upgrades associated with certain segments of
	Boardwalk Pipeline&#146;s natural gas pipelines which are expected to be completed in 2018.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Credit Risk
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Credit risk relates to the risk of loss resulting from the default by a customer of its contractual obligations or the
	customer filing bankruptcy. Boardwalk Pipeline actively monitors its customer credit profiles, as well as the portion of its revenues generated from investment-grade and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-investment-grade
</FONT>
	customers. A
	majority of Boardwalk Pipeline&#146;s customers are rated investment-grade by at least one of the major credit rating agencies,&nbsp;however, the ratings of several of its producer customers, including some of those supporting its growth projects,
	have been downgraded in the past year. The downgrades may restrict liquidity for those customers and indicate a greater likelihood of nonperformance of their contractual obligations, including failure to make future payments or, for customers
	supporting its growth projects, failure to post required letters of credit or other collateral as construction progresses.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Gulf South Rate Case
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Boardwalk Pipeline&#146;s Gulf South subsidiary filed a rate case with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission
	(&#147;FERC&#148;) in 2014 and reached an uncontested settlement with its customers in 2015, which was subsequently approved by the FERC and became effective on March&nbsp;1, 2016. The rate case settlement provided for, among other things, a
	system-wide rate design across the majority of the pipeline system, which resulted in a general overall increase in rates and implementation of a fuel tracker for determining future fuel rates on April&nbsp;1, 2016. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015,
	Boardwalk Pipeline had a $16&nbsp;million rate refund liability recorded, which was settled in April of 2016 through a combination of cash payments and invoice credits. Had the fuel tracker been implemented April&nbsp;1, 2015, revenues would have
	been lower by $18&nbsp;million and operating expense would have been lower by $13&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	62
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage63"></A>

<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-INSIDE:AVOID ; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Expenses:
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">

</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
</TD>

</TD>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	2016 Compared with 2015
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Total revenues increased $62&nbsp;million in 2016 as compared with 2015. Excluding the net effect of $13&nbsp;million of
	proceeds received from the settlement of a legal matter in 2016, $9&nbsp;million of proceeds received from a business interruption claim in 2015 and items offset in fuel and transportation expense, primarily retained fuel, operating revenues
	increased $83&nbsp;million. The increase was driven by an increase in transportation revenues of $71&nbsp;million, which resulted primarily from growth projects recently placed into service, incremental revenues from the Gulf South rate case of
	$18&nbsp;million and a full year of revenues from the Evangeline pipeline. Storage and PAL revenues were higher by $17&nbsp;million primarily from the effects of favorable market conditions on time period price spreads.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Operating expenses decreased $16&nbsp;million in 2016 as compared with 2015. Excluding receipt of a franchise tax refund of
	$10&nbsp;million in 2015 and items offset in operating revenues, operating costs and expenses increased $5&nbsp;million primarily due to higher employee related costs, partially offset by decreases in maintenance activities and depreciation expense.
	Interest expense increased $7&nbsp;million primarily due to higher average interest rates compared to 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Net income
	increased $15&nbsp;million in 2016 as compared with 2015, primarily reflecting higher revenues and lower operating expenses, partially offset by higher interest expense as discussed above.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	2015 Compared with 2014
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Total revenues increased $18&nbsp;million in 2015 as compared with 2014. Excluding the business interruption claim proceeds of
	$8&nbsp;million and items offset in fuel and transportation expense, primarily retained fuel, operating revenues increased $33&nbsp;million. This increase is primarily due to higher transportation revenues of $39&nbsp;million from growth projects
	recently placed into service, including the Evangeline pipeline which was acquired in October of 2014 and $20&nbsp;million of additional revenues resulting from the Gulf South rate case, partially offset by the effects of comparably warm weather
	experienced in the early part of the 2015 period in Boardwalk Pipeline&#146;s market areas and unfavorable market conditions. Storage and PAL revenues decreased $20&nbsp;million primarily as a result of the effects of unfavorable market conditions
	on time period price spreads.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Operating expenses decreased $80&nbsp;million in 2015 as compared with 2014. This decrease
	is primarily due to a $94&nbsp;million prior year charge to write off all capitalized costs associated with the terminated Bluegrass project, a $10&nbsp;million franchise tax refund related to settlement of prior tax periods and a decrease in fuel
	and transportation expense due to lower natural gas prices. These decreases were partially offset by higher depreciation expense of $35
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	63
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage64"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D284597D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	million from an increase in the asset base, including the Evangeline pipeline acquisition and a change in the estimated lives of certain older,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	low-pressure
</FONT>
	assets. Maintenance expense increased by $15&nbsp;million primarily due to pipeline system maintenance activities and the Evangeline pipeline acquisition. Interest expense increased
	$11&nbsp;million primarily due to higher average debt balances as compared with 2014, lower capitalized interest related to capital projects and the expensing of previously deferred costs related to the refinancing of Boardwalk Pipeline&#146;s
	revolving credit facility.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Net income increased $56&nbsp;million in 2015 as compared with 2014, primarily reflecting the
	prior year Bluegrass charge of $55&nbsp;million (after tax and noncontrolling interests) and higher revenues partially offset by higher depreciation and interest expense as discussed above.
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	2016 Compared with 2015
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Operating revenues increased $30&nbsp;million in 2016 as compared with 2015 primarily due to the acquisition of one hotel
	during 2016 and the acquisition of two hotels during 2015, partially offset by a decrease in revenue at the Loews Miami Beach Hotel due to renovations during 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Operating and depreciation expenses increased $22&nbsp;million and $9&nbsp;million in 2016 as compared with 2015 primarily due
	to the acquisition of one hotel during 2016 and the acquisition of two hotels during 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Equity income from joint
	ventures in 2016 was impacted by costs associated with opening one new hotel during 2016 and the $13&nbsp;million impairment of an equity interest in a joint venture hotel property.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Interest expense increased $3&nbsp;million in 2016 as compared with 2015 primarily due to new property-level debt incurred to
	fund acquisitions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Net income was consistent in 2016 as compared with 2015 due to the increases in revenues and expenses
	discussed above.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Loews Hotels expects to sell its equity interest in and conclude its management contract for the Loews
	Don CeSar Hotel, a joint venture hotel property, in the first quarter of 2017 and record a gain on the sale.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	64
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage65"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D284597D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	2015 Compared with 2014
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Operating revenues increased $129&nbsp;million in 2015 as compared with 2014 primarily due to the acquisition of two hotels
	during 2015 and three hotels during 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Operating and depreciation expenses increased $116&nbsp;million and
	$17&nbsp;million in 2015 as compared with 2014 primarily due to the acquisition of two hotels during 2015 and three hotels during 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Equity income increased $18&nbsp;million in 2015 as compared with 2014 primarily due to improved performance of the Universal
	Orlando joint ventures, partially offset by a $5&nbsp;million impairment of a joint venture equity interest in a hotel property.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Interest expense increased $7&nbsp;million in 2015 as compared with 2014 primarily due to higher debt levels, including
	refinancings and new property-level debt incurred to fund acquisitions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Net income increased slightly as compared to the
	prior year as higher income from Universal Orlando joint venture properties was partially offset by the negative impact of transaction and transition costs for hotels acquired during the year and higher interest expense. In addition, the effective
	tax rate increased due to an adjustment for prior years&#146; estimate and a higher state tax accrual for an increase in the ratio of Florida based income.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<A NAME="D284597D10K_HTM_TX284597_108">
</A>
	Corporate
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Corporate operations consist primarily of investment income at the Parent Company, corporate interest expenses and other
	corporate administrative costs. Investment income includes earnings on cash and short term investments held at the Parent Company level to meet current and future liquidity needs, as well as results of limited partnership investments and the trading
	portfolio.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The following table summarizes the results of operations for Corporate for the years ended December&nbsp;31,
	2016, 2015 and 2014 as presented in Note 20 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included under Item 8:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

	2015

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
	&nbsp;

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	2016 Compared with 2015
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Net investment income increased by $124&nbsp;million in 2016 as compared with 2015 primarily due to improved performance of
	equity based investments and fixed income investments in the trading portfolio and improved results from limited partnership investments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Operating expenses increased $15&nbsp;million in 2016 as compared with 2015 primarily due to expenses related to the 2016
	Incentive Compensation Plan, which was approved by shareholders on May&nbsp;10, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Net results improved by
	$68&nbsp;million in 2016 as compared with 2015 primarily due to the changes discussed above.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	65
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage66"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D284597D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	2015 Compared with 2014
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Net investment income decreased by $72&nbsp;million in 2015 as compared with 2014 primarily due to lower performance of
	equities and derivative related securities in the trading portfolio and lower results from limited partnership investments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Net results decreased by $51&nbsp;million in 2015 as compared with 2014 primarily due to the change in revenues discussed
	above and increased corporate overhead expenses.
</P>
</EFX_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS>
<EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<A NAME="FIS_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<A NAME="D284597D10K_HTM_TX284597_109">
</A>
	LIQUIDITY AND CAPITAL RESOURCES
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<A NAME="D284597D10K_HTM_TX284597_110">
</A>
	Parent Company
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Parent Company cash and investments, net of receivables and payables, at December&nbsp;31, 2016 totaled $5.0&nbsp;billion, as
	compared to $4.3&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2015. In 2016, we received $780&nbsp;million in dividends from our subsidiaries, including a special dividend from CNA of $485&nbsp;million. Cash outflows included the payment of $134&nbsp;million
	to fund treasury stock purchases, $8&nbsp;million to purchase shares of CNA, $84&nbsp;million of cash dividends to our shareholders and net cash contributions of approximately $20&nbsp;million to Loews Hotels. As a holding company we depend on
	dividends from our subsidiaries and returns on our investment portfolio to fund our obligations. We are not responsible for the liabilities and obligations of our subsidiaries and there are no Parent Company guarantees.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, there were 336,621,358 shares of Loews common stock outstanding. Depending on market and other
	conditions, we may purchase our shares and shares of our subsidiaries&#146; outstanding common stock in the open market or otherwise. In 2016, we purchased 3.4&nbsp;million shares of Loews common stock and 0.3&nbsp;million shares of CNA common
	stock. We have an effective Registration Statement on Form
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	S-3
</FONT>
	on file with the Securities and Exchange Commission (&#147;SEC&#148;) registering the future sale of an unlimited amount of our debt and equity
	securities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In March of 2016, Moody&#146;s Investors Service, Inc. (&#147;Moody&#146;s&#148;) downgraded our unsecured
	debt rating from A2 to A3, and the outlook remains stable. Our current unsecured debt ratings are A+ for S&amp;P Global Ratings (&#147;S&amp;P&#148;) and A for Fitch Ratings, Inc., with a stable outlook for both. Should one or more rating agencies
	downgrade our credit ratings from current levels, or announce that they have placed us under review for a potential downgrade, our cost of capital could increase and our ability to raise new capital could be adversely affected.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We continue to pursue conservative financial strategies while seeking opportunities for responsible growth. Future uses of our
	cash may include investing in our subsidiaries, new acquisitions and/or repurchases of our and our subsidiaries&#146; outstanding common stock.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<A NAME="D284597D10K_HTM_TX284597_111">
</A>
	Subsidiaries
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	CNA&#146;s cash provided by operating activities was $1.4&nbsp;billion in 2016 and 2015. Cash
	provided by operating activities in 2016 reflected increased receipts relating to the returns on invested capital for limited partnerships, lower income taxes paid, and offset by higher net claim and expense payments. In 2015, cash provided by
	operating activities reflected lower premiums collected and decreased receipts relating to returns on limited partnerships, offset by lower net claim payments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	CNA declared and paid dividends of $3.00 per share on its common stock, including a special dividend of $2.00 per share in
	2016. On February&nbsp;3, 2017, CNA&#146;s Board of Directors declared a quarterly dividend of $0.25 per share, and a special dividend of $2.00 per share payable March&nbsp;8, 2017 to shareholders of record on February&nbsp;20, 2017. CNA&#146;s
	declaration and payment of future dividends is at the discretion of its Board of Directors and will depend on many factors, including CNA&#146;s earnings, financial condition, business needs and regulatory constraints. The payment of dividends by
	CNA&#146;s insurance subsidiaries without prior approval of the insurance department of each subsidiary&#146;s domiciliary jurisdiction is limited by formula. Dividends in excess of these amounts are subject to prior approval by the respective state
	insurance departments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	66
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage67"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D284597D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Dividends from the Continental Casualty Company (&#147;CCC&#148;), a subsidiary
	of CNA, are subject to the insurance holding company laws of the State of Illinois, the domiciliary state of CCC. Under these laws, ordinary dividends, or dividends that do not require prior approval by the Illinois Department of Insurance (the
	&#147;Department&#148;), are determined based on the greater of the prior year&#146;s statutory net income or 10% of statutory surplus as of the end of the prior year, as well as timing and amount of dividends paid in the preceding 12 months.
	Additionally, ordinary dividends may only be paid from earned surplus, which is calculated by removing unrealized gains from unassigned surplus. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, CCC is in a positive earned surplus position. The maximum allowable
	dividend CCC could pay during 2017 that would not be subject to the Department&#146;s prior approval is $1.1&nbsp;billion, less dividends paid during the preceding 12 months measured at that point in time. CCC paid dividends of $765&nbsp;million in
	2016. The actual level of dividends paid in any year is determined after an assessment of available dividend capacity, holding company liquidity and cash needs as well as the impact the dividends will have on the statutory surplus of the applicable
	insurance company.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Diamond Offshore&#146;s cash provided by operating activities decreased approximately $90&nbsp;million
	in 2016 as compared with 2015, primarily due to lower cash receipts from contract drilling services of $705&nbsp;million, partially offset by a $585&nbsp;million net decrease in cash payments for contract drilling and general and administrative
	expenses, including personnel-related, maintenance and other rig operating costs and lower income taxes paid, net of refunds of $30&nbsp;million. The decline in cash receipts and cash payments related to contract drilling services both reflect an
	aggregate decline in contract drilling operations, as well as a lower cost structure and the favorable impact of cost control initiatives.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	For 2017, Diamond Offshore has budgeted approximately $135&nbsp;million for capital expenditures.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In 2016, Diamond Offshore completed four sale and leaseback transactions and received $210&nbsp;million in proceeds, which was
	less than the carrying value of the equipment. The resulting difference was recorded as prepaid rent with no gain or loss recognized on the transactions. For further information about these transactions, see Note 6 of the Notes to Consolidated
	Financial Statements included under Item 8.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, Diamond Offshore had $104&nbsp;million in
	borrowings outstanding under its credit agreement and was in compliance with all covenant requirements thereunder. As of February&nbsp;10, 2017, Diamond Offshore had no outstanding borrowings and $1.5&nbsp;billion available under its credit
	agreement to provide short term liquidity for payment obligations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In November of 2016, S&amp;P downgraded Diamond
	Offshore&#146;s corporate credit rating to BB+ from BBB, and, in January of 2017, further downgraded its corporate credit rating to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	BB-,
</FONT>
	with a negative outlook. Diamond Offshore&#146;s current corporate
	credit rating by Moody&#146;s is Ba2 with a stable outlook. Market conditions and other factors, many of which are outside of Diamond Offshore&#146;s control, could cause its credit ratings to be lowered further. A downgrade in Diamond
	Offshore&#146;s credit ratings could adversely impact its cost of issuing additional debt and the amount of additional debt that it could issue, and could further restrict its access to capital markets and its ability to raise additional debt. As a
	consequence, Diamond Offshore may not be able to issue additional debt in amounts and/or with terms that it considers to be reasonable. One or more of these occurrences could limit Diamond Offshore&#146;s ability to pursue other business
	opportunities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Diamond Offshore will make periodic assessments of its capital spending programs based on industry
	conditions and will make adjustments if it determines they are required. Diamond Offshore, may, from time to time, issue debt or equity securities, or a combination thereof, to finance capital expenditures, the acquisition of assets and businesses
	or for general corporate purposes. Diamond Offshore&#146;s ability to access the capital markets by issuing debt or equity securities will be dependent on its results of operations, current financial condition, current credit ratings, current market
	conditions and other factors beyond its control.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Boardwalk Pipeline&#146;s cash provided by operating activities
	increased $24&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to 2015, primarily due to increased net income, excluding the effects of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	items such as depreciation and amortization, partially offset by timing of accruals
	and the Gulf South rate refund.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	67
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage68"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D284597D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In 2016 and 2015, Boardwalk Pipeline declared and paid distributions to its
	common unitholders of record of $0.40 per common unit and an amount to the general partner on behalf of its 2% general partner interest. In February of 2017, the Partnership declared a quarterly cash distribution to unitholders of record of $0.10
	per common unit.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	In January of 2017, Boardwalk Pipeline completed a public offering of $500&nbsp;million aggregate
	principal amount of 4.5% senior notes due July&nbsp;15, 2027 and plans to use the proceeds to refinance future maturities of debt and to fund growth capital expenditures. Initially, the proceeds were used to reduce outstanding borrowings under its
	revolving credit facility. As of February&nbsp;13, 2017, Boardwalk Pipeline had $65&nbsp;million of outstanding borrowings and $1.4&nbsp;billion of available borrowing capacity under its revolving credit facility. During 2016, Boardwalk Pipeline
	extended the maturity date of the revolving credit facility by one year to May&nbsp;26, 2021. Boardwalk Pipeline has in place a subordinated loan agreement with a subsidiary of the Company under which it could borrow up to $300&nbsp;million until
	December&nbsp;31, 2018. Boardwalk Pipeline had no outstanding borrowings under the subordinated loan agreement.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	For 2016
	and 2015, Boardwalk Pipeline&#146;s capital expenditures were $590&nbsp;million and $375&nbsp;million, consisting of a combination of growth and maintenance capital. Boardwalk Pipeline expects total capital expenditures to be approximately
	$850&nbsp;million in 2017, primarily related to growth projects and pipeline system maintenance expenditures.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Boardwalk
	Pipeline anticipates that for 2017 its existing capital resources, including its revolving credit facility, subordinated loan and cash flows from operating activities, will be adequate to fund its operations. Boardwalk Pipeline may seek to access
	the capital markets to fund some or all capital expenditures for growth projects, acquisitions or for general business purposes. Boardwalk Pipeline&#146;s ability to access the capital markets for equity and debt financing under reasonable terms
	depends on its financial condition, credit ratings and market conditions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Off-Balance
</FONT>
	Sheet Arrangements
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, we did not have any
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	off-balance
</FONT>
	sheet
	arrangements.
</P>

<A NAME="eolPage69"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D284597D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Further information on our commitments, contingencies and guarantees is provided
	in the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included under Item 8.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<A NAME="D284597D10K_HTM_TX284597_113">
</A>
	INVESTMENTS
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Investment activities of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-insurance
</FONT>
	subsidiaries primarily include investments in
	fixed income securities, including short term investments. The Parent Company portfolio also includes equity securities, including short sales and derivative instruments, and investments in limited partnerships. These types of investments generally
	present greater volatility, less liquidity and greater risk than fixed income investments and are included within Results of Operations &#150; Corporate.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	We enter into short sales and invest in certain derivative instruments that are used for asset and liability management
	activities, income enhancements to our portfolio management strategy and to benefit from anticipated future movements in the underlying markets. If such movements do not occur as anticipated, then significant losses may occur. Monitoring procedures
	include senior management review of daily reports of existing positions and valuation fluctuations to seek to ensure that open positions are consistent with our portfolio strategy.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Credit exposure associated with
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-performance
</FONT>
	by counterparties to our derivative
	instruments is generally limited to the uncollateralized change in fair value of the derivative instruments recognized in the Consolidated Balance Sheets. We mitigate the risk of non-performance by monitoring the creditworthiness of counterparties
	and diversifying derivatives by using multiple counterparties. We occasionally require collateral from our derivative investment counterparties depending on the amount of the exposure and the credit rating of the counterparty.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Insurance
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	CNA maintains
	a large portfolio of fixed maturity and equity securities, including large amounts of corporate and government issued debt securities, residential and commercial mortgage-backed securities, and other asset-backed securities and investments in
	limited partnerships which pursue a variety of long and short investment strategies across a broad array of asset classes. CNA&#146;s investment portfolio supports its obligation to pay future insurance claims and provides investment returns which
	are an important part of CNA&#146;s overall profitability.
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_23"></A>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Net investment income after tax and noncontrolling interests increased $88&nbsp;million in
	2016 as compared with 2015. The increase was driven by limited partnership investments, which returned 6.3% in 2016 as compared with 3.0% in the prior year. Income from fixed maturity securities increased by $40&nbsp;million, after tax and
	noncontrolling
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	69
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage70"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D284597D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	interests, primarily due to an increase in the invested asset base and a charge in 2015 related to a change in estimate effected by a change in accounting principle.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Net investment income after tax and noncontrolling interests decreased $131&nbsp;million in 2015 as compared with 2014. The
	decrease was driven by limited partnership investments, which returned 3.0% in 2015 as compared with 9.7% in the prior year. Income from fixed maturity securities decreased by $30&nbsp;million, after tax and noncontrolling interests, driven by a
	$22&nbsp;million, after tax and noncontrolling interests, change in estimate effected by a change in accounting principle to better reflect the yield on fixed maturity securities that have call provisions. Additionally, income from fixed maturity
	securities decreased due to lower reinvestment rates, partially offset by favorable changes in estimates for prepayments for asset-backed securities. Additional information on the accounting change is included in Note 1 of the Notes to Consolidated
	Financial Statements included under Item 8.
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	Net realized investment results increased $73&nbsp;million in 2016 as compared with 2015,
	driven by lower OTTI losses recognized in earnings and higher net realized investment gains on sales of securities. Net realized investment results decreased $66&nbsp;million in 2015 as compared with 2014, driven by higher OTTI losses recognized in
	earnings and lower net realized investment gains on sales of securities. Further information on CNA&#146;s realized gains and losses, including CNA&#146;s OTTI losses and derivative gains (losses), as well as CNA&#146;s impairment decision process,
	is set forth in Notes 1 and 3 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included under Item 8.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	70
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016 and 2015, only 2% and 1% of CNA&#146;s fixed maturity portfolio
	was rated internally.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">

	available-for-sale
</FONT>

</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; TEXT-INDENT:2%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
	The following table presents the maturity profile for these
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	available-for-sale
</FONT>
</FONT>
	fixed maturity securities. Securities not due to mature on a single date are allocated based on weighted average life:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
